snippet: God save the king, as portrayed by Eddie Redmayne in the Donmar Warehouse's production of "Richard II," because he sure isn't up to saving himself.
abstract: God save the king, as portrayed by Eddie Redmayne in the Donmar Warehouse's production of "Richard II," because he sure isn't up to saving himself.
lead_paragraph: LONDON -- He's trapped up there, isn't he, that man on the stage in the throne? Embodied by Eddie Redmayne, the title character of Shakespeare's "Richard II" is seated, eyes closed, in full view of the audience before the start of Donmar Warehouse's production of Shakespeare's lyrical history play. And Richard might as well be a porcelain figurine -- exquisite, immobile, infinitely fragile. If someone were to tap him with the scepter he holds, he would surely shatter. God save the king indeed, you think, because he sure isn't up to saving himself.

headline.main: London Theater Journal: Porcelain Portrayal of a Fragile King
